title: How do I forecast hotel demand and avoid unprofitable business?
description: In our “Ask the Genie” series, our reader asked how to forecast hotel demand and avoid unprofitable business. Here’s the answer!
content: With the right tools and strategies, you can master the art of saying “no” to unprofitable business at your property while keeping your revenue growing. Let’s dive into how you can forecast demand and make sure every room booking is worth its weight in gold. ## Forecasting, Your Hospitality Crystal Ball Creating a solid forecast is like having a crystal ball for your property’s future. It’s not magic (although it might feel like it); it’s a smart strategy. Here are a few key factors to consider when you want to forecast demand: Historical Data Analysis Bylooking at past performance, you can spot seasonal trends, anticipatedemandduring local events, and prepare for those quiet Tuesdays that always seem to sneak up on you. Current Market Analysis Stay ahead of the game by monitoring market trends. Are your competitors dropping rates during midweek? Are they hiking prices for that annual cheese festival in town? Knowledge is power. Booking Pace Monitoring Booking pace tells you what’s happening right now. Analyze how quickly your rooms are filling up andadjust your strategyas needed. Bookings too slow? Maybe a special offer will help. Too fast? Time to up those rates. Customer Segmentation Not all guest segments are created equal. Identify which market segments—corporate, leisure, groups, or OTAs—bring the most value. Focus your efforts on these high-performing segments while deprioritizing those with lower profitability. Use Technology Using a revenue management system for data analysis and real-time pricing adjustments is like having a revenue Genie on your team. There are no spreadsheets, no stress, just actionable insights that help you stay ahead of the curve. Want to learn moreabout using forecast insights to optimize pricing and inventory, improve operational planning, and meet budget targets and exceed them? Read our mini-guide“Hotel Forecasting: How to Plan and Price More Strategically by Predicting Demand.” → ## Redirecting Unprofitable Business. Saying “No” Like a Pro Once your forecast is in place, it’s time to identify and gently (or not-so-gently) nudge unprofitable business out the door. Consider it as Marie Kondo-ing your bookings: if it doesn’t spark profit, let it go. Identify Low-Yield Channels and Segments Which channels or rate plans are filling your rooms with little return? High-commission OTAs and deeply discounted group contracts often fall into this category. Assess their profitability and adjust your approach accordingly. Apply Strategic Sales Restrictions - MinLOS (Minimum Length of Stay):For high-demand periods, requiring longer stays prevents one-night bookings that limit revenue potential. - Close low-yield channels:During peak dates, restrict availability on channels with high distribution costs. - Manage group bookings carefully:Monitor group rates and contracts to ensure they’re not undercutting your revenue goals. If a group deal isn’t profitable, it’s not worth the headache. Optimize Your Inventory Every room has revenue potential beyond its nightly rate: - Strategic room upgrades:Upsell premium rooms to guests willing to pay more. - Cross-selling services:Encourage guests to dine at your restaurant, visit the spa, or book activities, increasing total spend per guest. Focus on Direct Bookings Direct bookings are like your property’s golden eggs—they have low acquisition costs and high loyalty potential. Offer website-exclusive perks or loyalty rewards to make guests feel special and keep them returning. ## The Game Never Stops Revenue management is a marathon, not a sprint. Your forecast and restrictions aren’t static—they need to evolve with the market. Regular Strategy Reviews Set aside time to revisit your forecast andpricing strategy. Is your MinLOS still working as expected? Are there emerging trends in your market that you need to account for? Adjust accordingly. Track Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) Metrics like ADR (Average Daily Rate),RevPAR(Revenue Per Available Room), and GOPPAR (Gross Operating Profit Per Available Room) are your guiding stars. Use them to evaluate your performance and tweak your strategy as needed. “Hoteliers should monitor their RevPAR on a regular basis (as well as their other key metrics) to ensure that they are always pricing their rooms at the right price based on the current supply and demand in their destination. For example, when there is high demand but the property has a low occupancy rate, it likely means that they are pricing their rooms too high for the market to bear; by decreasing their room rates to be more in line with the competition, they will likely see their occupancy rates increase quickly. The opposite is also true: if there is very low demand but the property has high occupancy, the room rates are likely too low and should be increased to maximize revenue from each booking.”–José Miranda, Sales and Revenue Manager Spain Team Collaboration Revenue optimization isn’t just the responsibility of your revenue manager. Align your sales, marketing, and operations teams with your revenue goals to create a cohesive and practical approach. ## Turning Profitability into Second Nature Avoiding unprofitable business isn’t just about saying “no”; it’s about saying “yes” to the right bookings. So go ahead and start implementing these steps to ensure every booking contributes to your bottom line.
